Welcome to #WealthWednesday

This week, we'll be discussing Stress Management.

To have some pressure in our lives is normal. Some level of stress is an everyday reality. 
What is stress? It is a State of tension that arises when you experience demands from your environment or from inside yourself.

Stress sometimes comes during life-changes aka #adulting: Moving from Childhood to Adolescence to being a young adult. Getting to middle age, marriage, becoming a parent and aging are also stressful periods.

Whilst stress is inevitable, distress is not. Today, we would like to focus on you. Are you managing your stress well?

Are you stressed? Let‚Äôs do a Self-Check. 
Cognitive Symptoms -Memory problems, Inability to concentrate, Poor Judgment, Anxious or racing thought, less effective thinking

Emotional Symptoms ‚Äì Moodiness, Irritability or short temper, Inability to relax, Feeling overwhelmed, Sense of loneliness & Isolation, Depression or general unhappiness

Behavioral Symptoms - Eating more or less, Sleeping too much or too little, Isolating yourself from others, Procrastinating or neglecting responsibilities, Nervous habits (Nail biting, pacing), Missing deadlines/Argumentative

Physical Symptoms - Aches & Pains, Diarrhea or constipation, Nausea and / or dizziness, Chest pain /Rapid heartbeat, Frequent cold/low energy,  Constant tiredness #WealthWednesday #StanbicIBTC #TimeOut

If you identify some of these symptoms in yourself, you may be unduly stressed. Unhealthy stress levels could have adverse effects on your health. Related illnesses include:
Hypertension, Ulcers, Stroke, Depression, drug abuse, headaches, recurrent common ailment like Flu, recurrent malaria episodes  #WealthWednesday

Sometimes, work gets the better of us and leaves us stressed out. Which of these do you feel often?

Types of Workplace Stress

Time Stress ‚Äì Are you worrying about not having enough time? Could be due to a heavy workload or unrealistic deadline.

Situational Stress ‚Äì Some work situations involve conflict, or a loss of status with your colleagues. For instance, making a major mistake that your team is aware of.

Anticipatory Stress - This is stress experienced concerning the future. Anxiety about closing a specific deal or for an upcoming presentation, perhaps?

Encounter Stress - Encounter stress revolves around your interactions with clients or colleagues in the work place. Could be colleagues you don‚Äôt like or difficult clients. #WealthWednesday #StanbicIBTC

How to manage workplace stress ‚Äì

Create a balanced schedule: Analyze your schedule, responsibilities, and daily tasks. Try to find a balance between work and family life and social activity.

Distinguish between the ‚Äòshoulds‚Äô and the ‚Äòmusts‚Äô: Sort out the urgent and important from the nice to haves. Don‚Äôt overload yourself.

Plan regular breaks: Deliberately take short breaks throughout the day to take a walk or sit back and clear your mind. Stepping away from work to briefly relax and recharge will improve productivity.

Take a holiday: We mean a real holiday where you relax and can be adventurous- not just a shopping holiday.

Know your body: Your body speaks. Listen to it and seek medical advice when you feel unwell. 
Be deliberate about planning rest and recreation into your schedule. It will restore your creativity, fuel your vision, and bring balance to your world. #StanbicIBTC #WealthWednesday

Beyond work place stress, managing stress starts with:

a.  Fixing

b.  Accepting

c.  Protecting.

#WealthWednesday #StanbicIBTC

Whether you can remove the stressor or not, you should practice techniques to prevent the stress response from taking over your body.

How?
Exercise regularly: Be involved in any activity that raises your heart rate and relaxes your mind and body. 30 minutes of daily heart-pounding activity is recommended.

Laugh: Don‚Äôt take yourself too seriously. Try to find joy in everything.

Eat healthy and regularly: Eating small but frequent meals can help your body maintain an even level of blood sugar, keep your energy up, stay focused, and avoid mood swings.

Sleep well: Rest is a key factor in coping with workplace stress. Sleep for 6-8 hours every 24 hours.

Don‚Äôt get angry: Do not go beyond consternation into fury or rage. Anger brings on stress too.

Get a massage: A proper massage can help ease tense muscles and relieve pain and discomfort.

Drink water: Lots of water. You should aim to drink 6-8 glasses of water a day. #WealthWednesday #StanbicIBTC

#NeverStop  #MovingForward: It‚Äôs not just a tagline, aiming for constant progress helps you stay ahead of who you were yesterday.

Wait first, don‚Äôt faint yet. A trust could help you out here.

Meet Bolanle @bolashob ‚Äì she‚Äôs a live wire. She‚Äôs bubbly and has enough warmth to thaw an iceberg. She also leads the Client Experience team for our Pensions business. Her personal goal was simple enough: to increase her savings by 100% in 2016. She did it. How?

By creating a budget and sticking to it, reducing and prioritizing her expenses and setting up direct debit on her account. To help her achieve this, she credits the following principles... ‚Ä¢  Set realistic but stretchy goals: This will ensure that you don‚Äôt easily get discouraged and stay challenged. ‚Ä¢  Identify milestones: It is important to regularly stop and measure the level of success achieved on each goal. ‚Ä¢  Be accountable: For easy tracking and accountability, I had an accountability partner, this kept me in check and made it fun!

Meet Dele @sotubooladele: he enjoys eucalyptus tea and microwave-able popcorn.

As the Executive Director, Investment for our pension business, he takes no excuses and certainly does not mind getting his hands dirty. His resolution was to bring a project to 90% completion and he‚Äôs done it! To achieve a similar feat, he recommends: ¬∑  That you start by not calling it a resolution but you can adopt terms like goals, targets.
¬∑  If you have a goal, make more plans towards what you need to stop doing to achieve that goal instead of what you need to do to achieve it
¬∑  Where your lifestyle change puts extra cash in your pocket, don‚Äôt spend it. Save it!
¬∑  Do not procrastinate! What you need to do today, do it NOW!
¬∑  Don‚Äôt be too hard on yourself. If you drop a ball, pick it up and continue. Don‚Äôt give up!

Meet Steve - he never misses breakfast & lunch, fuelling up is essential! He is our Executive Director of Operations for our pension business and he wanted to spend more quality time mentoring the people in his closest circle. He achieved this goal and recommends the following steps: ‚Ä¢  Focus: I avoided setting too many goals. This focus helped me stay on track ‚Ä¢  Write them down: My goals were documented. No matter how small they are, writing your goals make them easier to track, remember and implement. ‚Ä¢  Put in the work: Achieving anything worthwhile takes effort. Don‚Äôt be afraid to sweat for it.

We want to share some really tropical information with you this #WealthWednesday

We are primarily concerned about your financial health but your physical & mental fitness is also important to us. #WealthWednesday

As end to end financial advisers, we have seen 1st-hand the stretchy impact of these challenging times on people. 
Things are really tough and people are very stressed. We owe it to ourselves to stay mentally healthy. #WealthWednesday

Today, we will be talking about depression. We begin with 4 things you should know about depression. 
Many of us think depression is simply sadness. It isn‚Äôt. Sadness is a normal reaction to difficult events and periods and we usually get over it. #WealthWednesday

Many of us think depression is simply sadness. It isn‚Äôt. Sadness is a normal reaction to difficult events and periods and we usually get over it.

Sadness is only a small part of depression. Some people with depression may not feel sadness at all. Depression has many other symptoms, including physical ones.

When a person has depression, it interferes with daily life & normal functioning. It can cause pain for the person with depression and those who care about them. #WealthWednesday

Depression is not a sign of a person‚Äôs weakness or a character flaw. It is important to not diminish people for being depressed. 
You can‚Äôt just ‚Äúsnap out of‚Äù clinical depression and most people who experience depression need treatment to get better. 
If you have been experiencing any of the following signs and symptoms for at least 2 weeks, you may be suffering from depression #WealthWednesday

There are many factors that play a role in depression. A few of them are: #WealthWednesday

Genetics, brain biology and chemistry, and life events such as trauma, loss of a loved one, a difficult relationship, an early childhood experience, or any stressful situation.

Depression can happen at any age, but often begins in the teens or early 20s or 30s. 
The severity and frequency of symptoms, and how long they last, will vary depending on the individual.

Even children can get depression. The child may pretend to be sick, refuse to go to school, cling to a parent, or worry that a parent may die. 
Because normal behaviors vary from one childhood stage to another, it can be difficult to tell if a child is just going through a ‚Äúphase‚Äù or is suffering from depression. #WealthWednesday

Older children and teens with depression may sulk, get into trouble at school, be negative and irritable, and feel misunderstood. 
If you‚Äôre unsure if an adolescent in your life is depressed or just ‚Äúbeing a teenager,‚Äù consider how long the symptoms have been present, how severe they are, and how different the teen is acting from his or her usual self. 
Teens with depression may also have other disorders such as anxiety, eating disorders, or substance abuse. They may also be at higher risk for suicide.

Adults with depression do not all experience the same symptoms. Typical symptoms include sadness, worthlessness, and guilt. #WealthWednesday

They are likely to be very irritable, lose interest in once-pleasurable activities, and have difficulty sleeping. They may act recklessly. 
Some people turn to alcohol or drugs when they are depressed. They also may become frustrated, discouraged, irritable, angry and abusive. 
Some may throw themselves into their work to avoid talking about their depression with family or friends. #WealthWednesday

Sometimes it can be difficult to distinguish grief from major depression. However, grief that is complicated and lasts for a very long time following a loss may require treatment. 
Older adults who had depression when they were younger are more at risk for developing depression in later life.

Depression, even the most severe cases, can be treated. The earlier treatment begins, the more effective it is.

Most adults see an improvement in their symptoms when treated with antidepressant drugs, talk therapy (psychotherapy), or a combination of both. #WealthWednesday

As the pressure of life mounts, we must be more watchful for those we love. Please notice the signs and symptoms and show some more understanding. 
If you think you may have depression, start by making an appointment to see your doctor or health care provider.

Just talk to someone. Many more people than you think will care. #WealthWednesday
There are different types of depression. Symptoms can range from relatively minor to very severe, so its helpful to be aware of the range of conditions and symptoms. #WealthWednesday

It‚Äôs that time of the week again ÔÅä and this time we will be discussing something that we rarely talk about‚Ä¶Estate Planning. 
Estate planning involves sorting out the disposal of your assets while you‚Äôre still alive and well. For the benefit of those you love #WealthWednesday
Having an estate plan is an essential part of preserving your assets. #WealthWednesday

Having an estate plan is an essential part of preserving your assets. 
The basics of protecting your assets for your family through estate planning involves Wills and Trusts. ‚ÄúHol‚Äôup, hol‚Äôup!‚Äù Yes, we know wills are a touchy subject but look at it this way: life is beautiful and unfair. 
Passing on has nothing to do with how old or healthy you are. Unfortunately, even children die right after they are born. 
Also, a Will is really just a document that lists the assets you have, who should get them and how they should get them when you pass on. #WealthWednesday

You may be thinking: ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt have assets, jare‚Äù Do you know the cash in your wallet right now is an asset? 
You probably also have money in your bank account and a Retirement Savings Account. What about those designer items? #WealthWednesday

‚Ä¶And even then, your assets could still be distributed using Customary Law. Sometimes to the detriment of those closest to you. 
This all sounds a bit depressing and it really is. Imagine others gaining the benefit of your life‚Äôs work while your loved ones struggle.

It‚Äôs time to put your wishes down in a Will to avoid family disputes and ensure your loved ones are well taken care of.

You know us. We‚Äôre discreet and quietly efficient at this. It‚Äôs our work. Email us SITLAgency@stanbicibtc.com with any questions! #WealthWednesday

A Trust lets you to set aside some assets for a particular objective by passing the rights to the assets to a trustee.

A quick explanation of the terms;
With a Living Trust, you get a first-hand experience of how your wishes would be adhered to when you pass on.

A Corporate Trust is a going concern and does not die, you are rest assured that the objective of the Trust would be adhered to.

Assets transferred into a Living Trust go to your beneficiaries in line with your wishes avoiding the delay and expenses of the Probate process. #WealthWednesday

And because Trust assets do not go through Probate, the trust is not subject to estate tax, when you pass on. 
You‚Äôre also assured of confidentiality under a Trust unlike a Will which is a public document that can be viewed in a court.

What‚Äôs the best thing about a trust? The assets are continually invested by our Investment Managers, so the assets grow to keep providing value.

Make a smart decision today by preserving your assets for your loved ones #WealthWednesday #EstatePlan #PreservingAssets

Hey listen, things happen so it's best to be prepared. 
Don‚Äôt wait to write your will, do it. If it seems hard to do, let‚Äôs help you.

Your pension contributions are deducted before tax, lowering your taxable income so you save on tax payments.

The mandatory contribution into your RSA should be 18% of your monthly emoluments #WealthWednesday

Emoluments are the sum of your basic salary, transport and housing allowance. #WealthWednesday

An SMS alert is sent 24 hours after your account is credited and guess what? SMS are 100% free! #nochargealert #WealthWednesday

Growing your wealth comes with taking some risks. Enjoying that wealth also has its risks. In fact, everything is risky now. Even Robert.

If you‚Äôre trying to decide on what to prepare for dinner @dobbysignature‚Äôs simple and delicious chicken stir fry recipe looks so good. #FoodieFriday #Food #Foodie #StanbicIBTC

Ingredients ‚Ä¢ 1/2 kilo of chicken ‚Ä¢ 1 tablespoon of curry powder ‚Ä¢ 1 tablespoon of thyme ‚Ä¢ 2 seasoning cubes ‚Ä¢ 2 medium sized onion ‚Ä¢ 3 tablespoon of vegetable oil ‚Ä¢ 3 tablespoon of soy sauce ‚Ä¢ 3 tablespoon of corn starch/ plain flour ‚Ä¢ 1 tablespoon of ginger, minced ‚Ä¢ 1 tablespoon of garlic, minced ‚Ä¢ 1 tablespoon of chili pepper ‚Ä¢ 2 medium sized green bell pepper ‚Ä¢ 3 medium sized red bell pepper ‚Ä¢ 1 handful green beans ‚Ä¢ 1 cup green peas ‚Ä¢ Salt to taste

How to prepare - Remove the seeds from the bell peppers, and chop them into long strips - Set this aside. Chop one onion and the green beans into large chunks - Set this aside. - Fillet the chicken and cut into smaller pieces. Add the seasoning cubes, curry, thyme, ginger, chili pepper and salt. Cook for 10 minutes. - Add the oil in a frying pan and heat for 15 seconds. Add the cooked chicken (without the stock) and fry for 2 minutes. -Add the onions to the chicken and stir-fry for 1 minute, then add the soy sauce, green peas and vegetables. Stir-fry for about 1-2 minutes. - To make the sauce, pour the corn starch or plain flour into the chicken stock and mix. Cook for about 3 minutes till it thickens. Pour this into the chicken stir-fry and mix. -Leave to simmer for about 2 minutes and serve hot.

Many of us have desk jobs and are generally less physically active than we should. Come on, guys. That‚Äôs bad üòï

You know how an uninhabited house deteriorates faster than an inhabited one? That‚Äôs how it works with an active vs. a sedentary body. 
No, really. Your muscles can atrophy, you may feel less optimistic and stairs become your nemesis. Do better #WealthWednesday

Being so career driven, let‚Äôs speak to your enlightened self-interest: being active can make you more productive at work. 
#WealthWednesday
None of these reasons compare to having to suffer through health issues that could have been avoided. #WealthWednesday
Some more ‚Äòlow-level‚Äô conditions that could be caused by not being active include ‚Äì Insomnia, bad sleep patterns, back aches, low energy levels and stress #WealthWednesday
Being aware of these should help you make the decision to become more physically active. Once you decide, start right away. #WealthWednesday
Find things you enjoy doing that don‚Äôt feel like exercise. Like to take photographs? Take frequent photo-walks around your home #WealthWednesday
Physical activity gets easier when you make it fun with friends and family. #WealthWednesday
Play hide and seek with your kids, your nephews and nieces. This will be fun, you spend time with your loved ones. #WealthWednesday
Take a stroll after dinner, take dance lessons, ride a bicycle, take the stairs at work #WealthWednesday
It doesn‚Äôt matter what you do, as long as you are doing something. Physical activity isn‚Äôt always planned exercise, #WealthWednesday
Truly, a physically active lifestyle is the first step to preserving your health. #WealthWednesday
We cannot overemphasize that exercise is key to preventing the early onset and complications of several medical conditions. #WealthWednesday
Don‚Äôt wait. Right now is a great time to get active. Just do it. #WealthWednesday

We work hard to keep your money and make you wealthier. You should do the same to keep your body and get healthier. #WealthWednesday

Meet Ada ‚Äì She got her first job in January...first salary this week! HR just called to ask for her RSA details. #WealthWednesday #Retirement #Future #RetireWell

What is RSA? 
RSA = Retirement Savings Account. It is the easiest way to ensure savings are targeted directly for retirement. #WealthWednesday

Ada asks Olu who just joined the company too: ‚ÄúHow does this RSA thing work? Do you know?‚Äù An RSA is an account funded by a percentage of your monthly salary. 18% of your salary to be specific. These contributions come from both you (8%) and your employer (10%) so 18% of your *total monthly pay. #WealthWednesday #Pension #SaveNow #Future #Retirement

You can decide to make your own extra contributions to your RSA. These are called voluntary contributions. This account, your RSA is managed for you by a Pension Fund Administrator (PFA). Hopefully usüòä. If it‚Äôs not us, WYD? #WealthWednesday #Pension #Retirewell

Your PFA gives you a personal identification number (PIN) for your RSA. This is your ‚Äúaccount number‚Äù aka RSA PIN. With your RSA PIN, you can check your account balance to know how much you‚Äôve saved for the future. #WealthWednesday

The PFA invests the money in your RSA to earn returns for you. Unlike bank accounts, you can have only one RSA. When the transfer window opens, you can move to us though. Yes, a transfer window closed last night, but we‚Äôre not talking football. #WealthWednesday

Companies with more than 3 employees must make pension contributions to their staff‚Äôs RSAs. Nigerian law says so. When you retire, you can get the money in your RSA pretty easily. We have paid over N200bn to our retirees so far #WealthWednesday

1.4m professionals like you trust us with their RSAs and their hopes and dreams for retirement. Partly because we‚Äôre easily reachable through many channels. On the phone, via webchat, on social media & in person. #WealthWednesday

Ask us anything else you want to know about pensions. We are here to make sure you retire well.üòä
#WealthWednesday

Jumoke Sanwo is an artist and lifestyle photographer. A graduate of English Studies from the Obafemi Awolowo University in Nigeria, she has had her works exhibited in New York, Brussels, Dubai, Lagos, Sudan, Addis Ababa, Benin, Chad & Ghana.

#TheFineArts
@Jumokesanwo works addresses aesthetic concerns as well as concerns on identity, which fosters the discourse on re-imaging the African Continent. She is a member of The X-perspective, Black Female Photographers Association, American Photography Association and Invisible Borders Trans-African Photography group.

#TheFineArts
@jumokesanwo has received many awards many awards including the Institut-Fran√ßais Award for Outstanding Project at the Biennale Benin 2011. Her ‚ÄúFaces Project‚Äù and Silence Des Femme was presented under the platform of Invisible Borders Trans African Project at the 2015 Venice Art Biennale.

#TheFineArts A man of two worlds, Muraina Oyelami is known by many as a master painter while others know him as a great performing artist in music and theatre. Oyelami began his career as an artist in 1964 as one of the original products of the famous Oshogbo Art School initiated by Professor Ulli Beier and his wife Georgina Beier.

#TheFineArts Oyelami studied Technical Theatre specialising in Theatre Design at the Obafemi Awolowo University, Ile Ife where he later taught traditional music from 1975 to 1987. Described by many as a poetic painter with a romantic touch, Oyelami‚Äôs works are a representation of his experiences, stories, folktales and landscapes.

#TheFineArts Oyelami has exhibited his works and performed traditional and fusion music throughout Europe, Asia, Africa, Australia and USA. Oyelami was also a founding member of the late Duro Ladipo Theatre Company as an actor and musician. He composed and directed the music for Wole Soyinka‚Äôs famous ‚ÄòDeath and the King‚Äôs Horseman‚Äô at the Royal Exchange Theatre, Manchester, England.

#TheFineArts Kainebi Osahenye studied at both Auchi Polytechnic, Auchi in 1986 and Yaba College of Technology, Lagos in 1989 majoring in painting. He has spent the last 20 years exploring different ways to interact with issues like religion, social injustice, and globalization. #kainebiosahenye

#TheFineArts Osahenye‚Äôs studio is filled with used paint tubes, water bottles, beverage cans, and other forms of detritus that the artist has been incorporating into much of his recent work. His work addresses issues of man‚Äôs inhumanity to man; a theme he has carried from his first exhibition in 1991. #kainebiosahenye

#TheFineArts Internationally renowned artist El Anatsui said, ‚ÄúI think Kainebi is one of the few artists within the Nigerian contemporary art context who is highly experimental and also much focused on opening up the possibilities of painting both as a medium and as process‚Äù. #kainebiosahenye

#TheFineArts Olumide Oresegun was born in Ikorodu, Lagos State. His love for drawing and painting started when he was 4. He had his formal education in Yaba College of Technology where he graduated with a distinction in Fine Art. This year, he received media attention in Nigeria and beyond when he posted some of his oil on canvas paintings on Facebook.

#TheFineArts Olumide Oresegun specializes in hyperrealism. His works look very close to digitally taken photos that you mistake them for it. He cites Pablo Picasso and Michelangelo di Ludovico Buonarroti Simoni as his role models. His drawing and painting are inspired by his environment, mostly using water as the principal theme of his works.
#TheFineArts @oluhyperclassical currently owns an art studio in Ikorodu where he showcases his works and exhibitions.

Gerald Chukwuma studied at the University of Nigeria, Nsukka where he majored in painting and graduated with a B.A (Hons. Fine and Applied Arts, First Class). He is known for sculptures made from materials he picks from the streets. They are planks or panels of various sizes to which he uses to make a whole without embellishments. He attaches eye-catchingly colorful images to them. #TheFineArts

Gerald Chukwuma has had 20 in the last decade across Nigeria, Cameroon, France, Denmark, Holland, and the United States. He was part of the exhibition ‚ÄòHeden Daagse Afrikaanse Kunst‚Äô Galerie 23 Amsterdam; ‚ÄòMusic Lesson‚Äô an exhibition of wood panels Alexis Galleries Lagos. Gerald has won several awards and is a full time studio artist. #TheFineArts

With his treatment of waste Gerald Chukwuma finds himself in the company of internationally esteemed artists such as El Anatsui (1944, born in Ghana, but living in Nigeria) who makes enormous, seemingly costly, undulating carpets or draperies from thousands of lead caps from wine bottles and of Pascale Marthine Tayou (Yaound√©, 1967). A form of artistic recycling that most Western art lovers beheld with some amazement. #TheFineArts

At the age of 20, Okhai Ojeikere started photography as a profession with a modest Brownie D camera without flash, and had a friend teach him the fundamentals of photography. He started out as a darkroom assistant in 1954 at the Ministry of Information in Ibadan. #TheFineArts

Ojeikere was a forerunner of documentary photography in Nigeria which he began in 1968. He produced an impressive portfolio of two thousand negatives documenting the ways women styled their hair into monumental headdresses. #TheFineArts

Ojeikere exhibited internationally in major venues such as the Venice Biennial, Tate Modern, Studio Museum in Harlem, Documenta, and Foundation Cartier pour l'Art Contemporain, among others. His son, Amaize Ojeikere, runs the studio Foto Ojeikere. Ojeikere died on 2 February 2014, at the age of 83. A large selection of Ojeikere's work was included in the arsenal section of the 55th Venice Biennale d'arte, "Il Palazzo Encyclopedia" curated by Massimiliano Gioni in 2013. #TheFineArts

Hey #foodies! @dobbysignature shredded ginger beef looks yummy. Why not try something different this weekend.
 #FoodieFriday #Foodie #Food
Ingredients
‚Ä¢ 1lb (pound) of boneless beef
‚Ä¢ 1 medium sized ginger ‚Ä¢ 6 cloves of garlic ‚Ä¢ 1 medium sized onion ‚Ä¢ 1 tablespoon of rosemary ‚Ä¢ 1 tablespoon of ground nutmeg ‚Ä¢ 2 tablespoons of chili pepper - ground ‚Ä¢ 2 seasoning cubes ‚Ä¢ Salt to taste ‚Ä¢ 2 cups of cucumber (optional)- diced ‚Ä¢ 1 cups of carrot (optional) - diced 
How to prepare
-Slice the beef into small stripes. Add salt, nutmeg, rosemary, crushed seasoning, onion, ginger and cook. -Cook for 30 minutes till it's tender. -Add the minced garlic, pepper and cook. - Reduce the heat then add the diced cucumber and carrot. Leave to simmer for 3 minutes on low heat. -Serve as a side dish with rice, yam, potato etc.

You save a lot when you buy in bulk. However, if you don't have the space to store them, team up with friends and neighbours to share the supplies- and the discount.

Hey foodies, try out Iced Coffee Frapp√© recipe by @dobbyssignature. #FoodieFriday #Drink #Foodie

Ingredients ‚Ä¢1 cup of milk ‚Ä¢1 tablespoon of sugar/honey ‚Ä¢2 tablespoons of instant coffee ‚Ä¢3 tablespoons of chocolate powder ‚Ä¢1 tablespoon of vanilla extract ‚Ä¢10 ice cubes ‚Ä¢1/3 cup of whipped cream

How to make Iced Coffee Frapp√©

Step 1: Pour the whipped cream and whip till it's fluffy - Set aside.

Step 2: In a blender, combine all the ingredients; cover and process until smooth. Pour into chilled glasses, top with whipped cream drizzled with chocolate syrup. Serve immediately.

Hey #Foodies! It‚Äôs finally the end of a long week. Settle in this weekend with this yummy potato casserole recipe by @dobbyssignature #FoodieFriday #food #Stanbicibtc

Ingredients ‚Ä¢ 4 medium sized Irish potatoes ‚Ä¢ 4 eggs ‚Ä¢ 1 medium sized chili pepper ‚Ä¢ 1 medium sized green pepper ‚Ä¢ 1/2 small onion ‚Ä¢ 1/2 cup of milk (1tbsp. powdered milk + 1/2 cup water) ‚Ä¢ 1/2 tablespoon salt ‚Ä¢ 1/2 cup of flour 
Method of preparation. - Dice the green pepper, chili pepper, onion and potatoes - Set aside - Place potatoes and water in a microwave or oven. Cover and bake on high for 7 minutes or until tender then drain. Alternatively, you could steam the chopped Irish potatoes for about 5 minutes and drain before adding it to the mixture. - Beat the eggs well, add the milk, salt and flour and mix. Gently add the veggies including the potato and stir well to incorporate. - Pour the mixture into an oven proof pan or dish and place in the oven. Bake, uncovered, at 350¬∞ for 30-40 minutes or until center is set on medium heat till it firms up. Serve!

Ingredients ‚Ä¢ 2¬Ω heaped cups all-purpose flour ‚Ä¢ 2 tablespoons of baking powder ‚Ä¢ 3 tablespoons of sugar ‚Ä¢ 2 cups of milk ‚Ä¢ 1 egg ‚Ä¢ ¬Ω tablespoon of salt ‚Ä¢ 4 tablespoons of butter - melted ‚Ä¢ Pancake syrup (to serve) - optional

#FinancialTip Keep business and personal finances separate.

One of the biggest mistakes that small #business owners make is to use their business #account as a personal account and vice versa. If you adopt this practice you cannot keep track of its profitability, especially if you are using debt to fund it. If you do not know what your net #profit is, there is no way you can know how to increase it.

Ramadan is on, try out this delicious gizpotato (gizzard & potato) recipe by @dobbyssignature for your #Iftar meal. Tag a friend who would droll for this #FoodieFriday #Ramadan

Ingredients ‚Ä¢ 2 cups gizzard ‚Ä¢ 2-3 cloves garlic - optional ‚Ä¢ 1 tablespoon of dry pepper - ground ‚Ä¢ 1/2 teaspoon of thyme ‚Ä¢ 1/2 medium size onion ‚Ä¢ 1/2 cup chopped green pepper ‚Ä¢ 1/2 cup chopped red bell pepper ‚Ä¢ 3 red scotch bonnet pepper (Ata rodo) ‚Ä¢ 4 pieces of tomatoes ‚Ä¢ 2 seasoning cubes ‚Ä¢ salt to taste ‚Ä¢ 5 medium sized irish potatoes ‚Ä¢ 1 large sweet potato - optional ‚Ä¢ 4 cups vegetable oil for deep frying 
Method of preparation -  Cut the potato into cubes and sprinkle some salt over it. Deep fry in pre-heated oil till brown ‚Äì set this aside. -  Cut up the gizzard into smaller pieces. Season the gizzard with pepper, garlic, chopped onion, thyme, salt and a little dry pepper. Allow to marinade for 20 minutes. Steam in a small pot till cooked for about 5 minutes, you want the gizzard to remain crunchy and not soft. Take out the cooked gizzard and keep the stock. -  Chop the green bell pepper, red bell pepper, onion and set this aside. -  Heat 2 tablespoon of oil in the frying pan and fry the cooked gizzard till brown. Add the chopped peppers, chopped tomatoes and onion. Season and add salt to taste then stir-fry for 1 minute. -  Add the fried plantain and mix the vegetables and potato well. Leave for about 2 minutes and its ready. -  Serve hot!

Who else is feeling the tomato scarcity? This @dooneyskitchen tomato less stew recipe will save you a lot of money. No need to worry about spending so much on cooking your favourite stew this long weekend.

Ingredients
10 pieces tatashe (Red bell pepper)

10 pieces shombo (Long red chilli)

10 pieces of ata rodo (Scotch bonnet pepper)

4 Ginger

3 bulbs of onions

Iru (Fermented locust beans) - to taste

Vegetable oil

1 1/2 kilo of beef

Palm oil (Optional) 
Instructions - Blend all the ingredient to a smooth puree -Boil the puree - Heat up oil, add some chopped onion. Add extra iru, oil or garlic if you want and allow to fry till it has thickened. - Add your beef stock and cow meat to cook for 5 minutes.

The weekend is here, why not give your family a treat with @dooneyskitchen yam pancakes for breakfast. #FoodieFriday #Food

Ingredients ‚Ä¢  Boiled yam ‚Ä¢  Chopped mixed vegetable- onion, chilies, spring onions, bell pepper. ‚Ä¢  2 eggs ‚Ä¢  Salt ‚Ä¢  Seasoning cubes - optional ‚Ä¢  Vegetable oil

Method of preparation - Boil your yam and use a potato masher or a food processor to turn it into mash. - Add the chopped vegetables and eggs. - Once its thick, season with salt and /or season cubes. - Heat up your frying pan with little oil. Scoop on the batter and spread into a wider circle. - Cook on medium heat to allow the pancake cook properly on one side without burning, so you can flip it over to cook. - When the pancake is brown, take it out of the pan and repeat the process. - Make your pancakes even sweeter by drizzling some honey all over them.

Why not try this salad recipe from @dobbyssignature 
Ingredients ‚Ä¢ 1 medium sized cabbage
‚Ä¢ 1 small sized cucumber
‚Ä¢ 5 lettuce leaves
‚Ä¢ 3 medium sized carrots
‚Ä¢ 3 small tomatoes
‚Ä¢ 1 medium sized green pepper
‚Ä¢ 2 cups sweet corn
‚Ä¢ 1 cup green peas
‚Ä¢ 2 cups macaroni ‚Äì boiled
‚Ä¢ 4 eggs

Method of preparation - Chop and slice the cabbage, cucumber, lettuce, tomatoes, green bell pepper and carrots into desired size. - Mix all the vegetables in a bowl and put into the refrigerator to chill. - To serve, simply dish out into small bowls and drizzle some salad cream or mayonnaise over it. Serve alone as an appetizer or as a side with any rice dish.

Solve this fruit teaser ‚ò∫

The answer is 21 üòÉ

Line one: the mango is equivalent to 7

Line two: 5 + 7 = 12; the grape is equivalent to 12

Line three: 1 + grape bunch = 7; banana bunch is equivalent to 6 because 6 + 1 = 7 (note: there are three orange in the bunch so 1 orange by itself would equal 2 since 6 divided by 3 equals 2)

Line four: 7 + 12 + 2 = 21

Why not try out Afia Efere for the weekend. Here is a quick and simple recipe by @dobbyssignatures #FoodieFriday #Food

Ingredients 
‚Ä¢ 1 kilo chicken ‚Ä¢ 3 tablespoons of dry pepper ‚Ä¢ 3 tablespoons of crayfish ‚Ä¢ 1 cup of periwinkles ‚Ä¢ 1 large dry fish ‚Ä¢ 4 medium pieces yam (for thickening) ‚Ä¢ 2 seasoning cubes ‚Ä¢ Salt to taste ‚Ä¢¬†Uyayak pod (tetrapleura tetraptera) 

Method of preparation -Roast the Uyayak pod in the oven for a few minutes. -Break the Uyayak pod into two parts and grind the other part into fine powder. Pour the ground powder into some water and stir. Pour the mix through a fine mesh sieve and set aside. -Boil the yam, pound in a mortar and set aside.¬†Cook the chicken into a medium sized pot and add the dry pepper, salt to taste and the seasoning cubes (crushed). -Steam for about 10 minutes. This allows the chicken to cook in its own juices which would come out of it once it starts to cook. Leave to cook for about 10 minutes. -Once the chicken is tender, pour in the sieved liquid from the Uyayak pod into the chicken stock in the pot and drop the other half into the pot. -Add in the dry fish and the pounded yam - stir, add the ground crayfish then cover and cook for another 5-10 minutes. Once the soup thickens to your desire, stir turn off the burner and set aside -Serve with pounded yam or garri

Cheers to the weekend fam! Add a little spice to your weekend with this okro-banga soup by @dooneyskitchen #FoodieFriday #Food #Foodie 
Ingredients
‚Ä¢	Banga - palm fruit extract
‚Ä¢	Beef stock
‚Ä¢	Uyayak - aidan fruit
‚Ä¢	Banga spices
‚Ä¢	Chopped okro
‚Ä¢	Fresh pepper - You can also use dry pepper
‚Ä¢	Smoked fish
‚Ä¢	Stockfish
‚Ä¢	Iru- fermented locust beans
‚Ä¢	Ground crayfish
‚Ä¢	Atama - dried native aromatic herbs
‚Ä¢	Uziza leaves
‚Ä¢	Salt
‚Ä¢	Seasoning cubes
‚Ä¢	Seafood (shrimps, crabs

How-to-prepare
-Add the palm fruit extract, beef stock and enough water to cook the quantity of okro that you have. Add the uyayak and a cooking spoonful of ground banga spice to the pot.
-Chop the okro and fresh pepper.
-While your banga stock is boiling, add the fresh shrimps and cook till pink then set aside.
-Add your boiled assorted meat, iru, stockfish and ground crayfish to the pot and leave to cook for 5 minutes.
-Add the chopped okro and pepper to the pot and stir.
-Crush dried atama leaves between your palms and add to the pot, add the chopped uziza leaves and leave to cook.
-Serve with garri or pounded yam.

#FinancialTip: Know your average recurring monthly expenses.

This is really hard for a lot of people to ascertain. The best way to determine your monthly expenses is to make a list of your household expenses, keep your receipts, your utility bills, and other expenses that arise during the month. This will help in determining your average recurring expenses.

Are you wondering what to prepare for the weekend? Well, we‚Äôve got a great meal idea for you to prepare, mushrooms with cauliflower. Here is a quick recipe @dobbyssignature #FoodieFriday #Food 
Ingredients 
‚Ä¢ 1 cup of beef stock
‚Ä¢ 300g of mushrooms 
‚Ä¢ 4 plum tomatoes
‚Ä¢ 1 tablespoon of curry powder
‚Ä¢ 2 seasoning cubes
‚Ä¢ 1 bulb of onion
‚Ä¢ ¬Ω small cauliflower
‚Ä¢ 2 medium sized yellow bell pepper 
‚Ä¢ A handful of scent leaf 
‚Ä¢ 3 fresh bay leaf 
‚Ä¢ Salt to taste

How-to-prepare
- Chop the tomatoes, yellow pepper, cauliflower and onion into large chunks ‚Äì set aside. Wash and slice the scent leaf and bay leaf. 
- Pour the beef stock in a pot, add the seasoning, curry powder, salt and a little chopped onion. Cook for 10 minutes. 
- Add the washed mushrooms and cook for another 10 minutes. 
- Add the chopped tomato, bay leaf, yellow pepper, cauliflower and onion into the pot and leave to simmer for 5 minutes. 
- Serve with rice or yam.

Etinkeni Ikong an Efik meal is an easy to make with assorted meat. It's irresistible aroma will leave your mouth watering even before you taste it. Try out @dooneyskitchen easy recipe. #Foodie #FoodieFriday #food

Ingredients 


¬∑  2 bunches of uziza 
¬∑  2 bunches of waterleaf 
¬∑  Assorted meats 
¬∑  Periwinkles 
¬∑  Palm oil 
¬∑  Stock fish 
¬∑  Smoked fish 
¬∑  Snails - Optional 
¬∑  Ponmo 
¬∑  Salt ‚Äì to taste 
¬∑  Seasoning cubes 
¬∑  Crayfish 
¬∑  3-5 pieces of yellow pepper 


How-to prepare 

- Season and boil your assorted meats. Add the fish to boil. When the meat is soft, add roughly blended yellow pepper and stir. 
-When the meat stock is almost dry, chop 2 bunches of waterleaf thinly, then add 2-3 cooking spoons of palm oil to the pot and allow to cook. 
-Add the grounded crayfish and perwinkles, then stir. 
-Add the waterleaf and stir till they wilt. 
-Then add the chopped uziza leaves, stir and cook for 2 minutes. 
- Ready to eat.

There has been an outbreak of the viral disease known as Lassa Fever in Nigeria in recent weeks with reported cases in 8 states; Bauchi, Nasarawa, Niger, Taraba, Kano, Rivers, Edo and Oyo.
In order to prevent infection with Lassa Fever, please maintain these simple health habits: ‚Ä¢ Put foods away in rodent-proof containers.
‚Ä¢ Keep your homes clean to discourage rodents.
‚Ä¢ Avoid unnecessary body contact.
‚Ä¢ Avoid sharing of sharp objects such as clippers or blades.
‚Ä¢ Practice safe sex.
‚Ä¢ Maintain high personal hygiene.

Please stay safe.

Here is something different you can prepare for your guests coming over for Christmas - mixed juice #FoodieFriday #Food #Foodie Photo credit: @dobbyssignature

Ingredients ‚Ä¢ ¬Ω small sized beetroot ‚Ä¢ 2 medium sized carrot ‚Ä¢ 1 cup pineapple - chopped ‚Ä¢ 2 cups coconut water 
Method of preparation -Peel the beetroot, carrot and pineapple and place in a blender. -Blend all together till smooth with a little water and strain. -Mix the coconut water with the strained juice and refrigerate. -Serve chilled.

Hello foodies, does it feel like Christmas yet? Perhaps some Efere Ibaba would put you in the mood? Repost by @dooneyskitchen  It‚Äôs a quick and easy recipe. #FoodieFriday #Foodie #Food

Ingredients
Goat meat
Stockfish
Smoked fish
Palm oil - or palm fruit extract
Salt to taste
Dry pepper
Fresh pepper
Etinkirin leaves - Uziza
Smoked red prawns
Ground ibaba powder - Ukpo
1 piece of uyayak - aidan fruit
Seasoning cubes
Ground crayfish

Method of preparation
-Season and boil your meat till tender. Add dry pepper, stockfish, smoked fish, smoked prawns and the uyayak, to infuse flavour into the stock.
-Add 1 cooking spoon of palm extract to the stock.
-Then add the Ibaba powder and stir.
-Mix achi with the some of the ground crayfish, stir in 2 table spoonfuls of the mixture to thicken.
- Add some extra ground crayfish, lower the heat and cook for 5 minutes.
-Add in some chopped uziza, plus extra heat, add some chopped fresh pepper. Remember to take out the uyayak, before serving, and ready to eat. -Serve with any swallow of your choice.

Trivia Thursday: Which Nigerian landmark is this?

The Cathedral Church of Christ, Marina Lagos. It is the oldest Anglican cathedral in Nigeria and one of the finest in Africa. Established in 1869, the church was designed by Architect Benjamin Bagandogi and stands on a prominent position at CMS on the Marina of the Lagos Island, overlooking the Lagos lagoon.

Do you remember Nma Jewel @nigerianlazychef #ADayInTheLife? Here is an exclusive recipe of delicious smoked mackerel stew and rice from her, just for you. #FoodieFriday #Foodie #Food

Ingredient

1 large roasted or smoked mackerel (flaked)

6 plum tomatoes

6 yellow chilies

2 sweet red tatashe

1 bell pepper (Tatashe)

1 bay leaf

2 tablespoons of powdered crayfish

1¬Ω medium onions

2 cooking spoons of palm oil 
Method of preparation -Blend all the peppers, tomatoes and onion. Pour into a fine mesh sieve to drain the excess liquid. -Heat the oil until very hot, but not to bleach. Add the sliced onions along with the bayleaf and saut√© until translucent. -Stir in the crayfish and leave to mix in for about another minute. Then pour in the tomato, pepper and stir. -Season with salt and or bouillon and cook until the oil floats to the top. -Add in the fish and stir. Cook for another 5 minutes. -Ready to eat.

Of the millions of Nigerians suffering from limb loss, almost 2 million are children.

Little Semilore Kosoko has a congenital limb defect. When she was born, she was missing a femur in her right leg.

Semilore is still very much a baby and lives with her grandmother in Ijoko. Her parents are separated and her mother has to be in Lagos to try to earn money  with her petty trading.

Growing up is tough and being born without a limb means that Semilore already has to deal with some stigmatization. For something she has absolutely no control of.

We have fitted Semilore with an orthotic prosthetic limb to help her walk and boost her confidence. Semilore also gets an educational trust from Stanbic IBTC Trustees to ensure that she can go to school without grandma having to worry about the fees.

In partnership with the Irede Foundation, we want to help to raise awareness and give hope to children with similar cases. #OutForALimb

We will be going #OutForALimb tomorrow to help raise awareness of the plight of underserved children who have to go through childhood without limbs.
Follow the stories with the hashtag #OutForALimb in partnership with the Irede Foundation.

Basirat Adam was hit by an okada and was taken to a local bonesetter for treatment and by the 3rd day, the injured leg had become dark from infection - this invariably led to amputation.

Basirat is only 13 years old and in J.S.S 1, her mother is widowed.

She loves to read and says English Language is her best subject. She aspires to become a Medical Doctor in order to help sick children.

#OutForALimb is our effort to help raise awareness and give hope to children with similar cases. We want to help even more children #NeverStop #MovingForward

Did you know that you can check your pension account balance on any Stanbic IBTC ATM nationwide?

Simply follow the steps:

Step 1: Visit any Stanbic IBTC ATM near you.
Step 2: Press 0 on the ATM key pad to initiate a cashless transaction.
Step 3: Select 'pension'
Step 4: Select the required service ('RSA balance' or 'RSA statement' as applicable) and press 'proceed'. Step 5: Enter your 12 digit RSA pin 'PENxxxxxxxxxxxx' and press 'proceed' (Please note that PEN is already displayed on this screen). Step 6: On the next screen, input your RSA pass code and press 'proceed'. Step 7: Upon confirmation of your RSA credentials, the information you require on your pension account will be displayed on the ATM screen.

For more information, please call 01 271 600, send an email to pensionsolution@stanbicibtc.com or visit www.stanbicibtcpension.com

Don‚Äôt know what to cook for the weekend? How about a delicious miyan zogale soup? Try out @dobbyssignatures recipe. #food #foodporn #FoodieFriday 
Ingredient ‚Ä¢ ¬Ω kg meat ‚Ä¢ 1 medium size dried fish ‚Ä¢ 2 large bunch of moringa leaves ‚Ä¢ 3 large size fresh tomatoes ‚Ä¢ 3 medium size fresh pepper ‚Ä¢ 1 medium size onion ‚Ä¢ 1 tablespoons yaji ‚Ä¢ ¬Ω cup of groundnut ‚Ä¢ 1 tablespoon of kaun "potash" ‚Ä¢ 1¬Ω litres water ‚Ä¢ 2 cooking spoon of palm oil ‚Ä¢ 3 seasoning cubes ‚Ä¢ Salt to taste 
Method of preparation - Boil the zogale leaves with ¬Ω litre of water and kaun for 5-8 minutes. Drain and set aside. - Cut the tomatoes and onion into small pieces and grind the pepper. - Roast the groundnut slightly for about 5 minutes without oil. Fry for about 10 minutes while stirring constantly, then peel off the skin and grind in a blender to a smooth paste. -Season the meat and steam for 10 minutes till the meat is tender. Fillet the fish and add into the stock to cook for 5 minutes. -Stir-fry the chopped tomatoes, onions and the ground pepper for 10 minutes, then add the groundnut paste into the pot. - Add the meat with the stock, ground dawadawa, crushed seasoning and yaji, stir and allow to boil for about 15minutes. Add the Zogale leaves and leave to simmer for 3 minutes. -Serve hot.

#ADayInTheLife of a Chef Dunni Obata @dooneyskitchen

Dunni is an IT Project Manager by day and a food blogger in the evenings. Hobbies include: flipping through cookbooks, watching cooking shows, reading and travel. I love Nigerian delicacies because of the bold flavours, contrasts of colours and the sheer number of dishes. My craziest creation would have to be Oreo Mosa balls - I paired a biscuit with over ripe plantains, which had never been done before and it turned out really well. ‚ÄúMy average morning starts at 8am when I prepare to go into the office for my day Job as an IT Project Manager. I'm a food blogger in the evenings and that begins with mostly responding to comments on the blog and on the social media sites of Dooney's Kitchen and rummaging through my kitchen and freezer for inspiration on what to cook." (1/5) #cheflife #chef #food

"They don't call me the gadget queen for nothing. I have two food processors, a stand mixer, a hand mixer, a hand blender, a ninja blender, and many more I can't even list. If there is a gadget to cut my cooking time considerably, I will buy it. Discovering all the ways you can use kitchen gadgets designed by people who never in their wildest dreams thought it could be used for Nigerian food makes me feel very empowered. The modern Nigerian woman wherever in the world she lives in has evolved from the time of her mother's generation and she needs all the help she can get, if she wants to keep churning out fantastic Nigerian meals and juggle family, career, business and life in general." (2/5) #cheflife #chef #food#ADayInTheLife

"I decided to venture out into providing dishes that I cook in my kitchen to people's homes. I have fun and rememberable names for our everyday Nigerian dishes such as surf and turf okro, pescatarian, squishy yam pottage, death by meat and the efo riro." (3/5) #cheflife #chef #food #ADayInTheLife

"Cooking has always been an outlet to physically live out creative ideas I have in my head. The other thing that drives me are my blog readers and social media followers. They have become like a wider family, and I have been able to reach out and interact with more people through what I do. They are very encouraging and supporting, they provide the best cooking tips out there, which drives me to do more and live up to their expectations." (4/5) #cheflife #chef #food #ADayInTheLife #foodporn

"What inspired me was the need to stop giving out the same recipe to different people when asked at different times. The time came to have an online document of my recipes which can easily be referred to. Not long after I started, I realised that there was a gap in the food blogging market that I could fill by sharing real life stories with cooking. Many of us learnt how to cook from the women and in some cases the men in our lives and that process usually involved some form of storytelling.‚Äù ( 5/5) #ADayInTheLife #cheflife

I‚Äôm Shade Yusuph, a handbag designer. ‚ÄúThe first thing I do after praying is planning, which I achieve by doing a quick list of set goals for the day in a chronological order. After this, I sketch the designs I hope to create and set out to find the most suitable fabrics. I believe that you can never use up creativity, the more you use the more you have. I am always on the lookout for better fabrics and I constantly try to draw up better designs and seek other items (e.g. beads, stones) that would make my work unique.‚Äù (1/4) #designer #bags #stanbicibtc #MovingForward

‚ÄúI‚Äôm confident that I can beat any competition with persistence. Every day, I give myself a target to do something new, I set no boundaries and I am very experimental - I have made purses put of 'gele' and right now, I also have hand-painted purses. While working, I check my social media accounts to post and catch up with fashion trends. I try to ensure good customer relationships by posting pictures of people I make purses and bags for, posting testimonials, getting feedback and managing inquiries.‚Äù (2/4) #thej5cway #bag #creative #ADayInTheLife

‚ÄúSome of the challenges I face is not being able to 'copyright' my designs and not being able to get exclusive fabrics. It's very frustrating when you create a design and it's being copied even before you can make money off it. Also, sourcing the right fabrics is a major issue and it would have been easier if we had textile producing industries that could help recreate one's designs on a small scale. Another challenge is not having the right platform(s) to showcase your works.‚Äù (3/4) #bag #creativity #ADayInTheLife

‚ÄúMy day ends with me posting pictures of my completed day's work on social media and getting ready to dispatch items the next day which I do via an independent courier service in Lagos.‚Äù (4/4) #bag #designer

You may not be able to get enough of shredded fish stir-fry, from this recipe. You can eat it with anything. Here‚Äôs how to make it. #food #foodie #FoodieFriday Photo credit: @dobbyssignature

Ingredient
‚Ä¢1 medium sized smoked ‚ÄúTitus‚Äù fish
‚Ä¢¬Ω bulb of onion
‚Ä¢1 small bunch of spring onions
‚Ä¢1 large green pepper
‚Ä¢1 tablespoon of curry powder
‚Ä¢3 tablespoons of vegetable oil
‚Ä¢¬Ω seasoning cube ‚Ä¢Salt to taste

Method of preparation
-Chop the onion, green pepper and spring onions.
- Remove the skin and bones from the fish, then wash and shred with your fingers.
-Pour the vegetable oil into the pan; add the vegetables, curry powder, seasoning and salt. Leave to fry for 3 minutes.
- Add the shredded fish; stir continuously for 4 minutes.
-Serve hot.

Welcome to #ADayInTheLife: where you will discover what daily living is like for Nigerian entrepreneurs and professionals. Watch this page as we share inspiring and captivating stories of chefs, models, bloggers, designers etc. and celebrate their awesomeness. Learn how they start off their day, overcome challenges and what motivates to keep moving forward.

#ADayInTheLife of A Chef Nma Okpara @Nigerianlazychef

This is Nma and she‚Äôs a foodie. She sees cooking as an art (we do too, by the way üòÄ), and considers her meals as her own contribution to the arts in general. @NigerianLazyChef says ‚ÄúI used to have the idea that Nigerian food was nothing more than ‚Äòrice‚Äô, ‚Äòbeans‚Äô, and ‚Äòyam‚Äô ‚Äì some of our very popular staples.‚Äù (1/5) #ADayInTheLife #cheflife #chef

‚ÄúI used to get quite tired of cooking the same thing over and over again, and my ‚Äòajebutters‚Äô (my kids) were also tired of the continuous "Nigerian food" cycle. Because of that, my exploring began. I started trying new things and developing simple recipes.‚Äù ( 2/5) #ADayInTheLife

‚ÄúA typical day in my life would start early with a walk through my kitchen with tea in hand - I usually plan breakfast, lunch and dinner and if I have a post planned, I do the prep work during this time.‚Äù (3/5) #ADayInTheLife

‚ÄúI really am my own worst critic and best supporter. In the competitive market, I try my best to please the customer and consumer while preserving my "chef" integrity. In this market, understanding my customers‚Äô needs, likes, and wants, is my top priority. For example, most of my clients like Nigerian soups and stews with fresh ingredients so, I always visit the farmer's market where I can find fresh local and international ingredients.‚Äù (4/5) #ADayInTheLife

‚ÄúOriginality also helps in the competitive market. Once you find your niche, the sky is your limit. I had to find that thing I was good at, a signature that would work for me. I think I have found it, and although it works very great and I am grateful for how far I have come, I believe that I am still a work in progress.‚Äù (5/5) #food #foodporn #cheflife #ADayInTheLife

Groundnut soup sounds great for lunch with the family for the weekend. Why don‚Äôt you give this a shot? Photo credit: @dobbyssignature #FoodieFriday #foodie #likeit

Ingredients
‚Ä¢ 1 kg of beef
‚Ä¢ 500g of assorted meat (shaki, ponmo etc)
‚Ä¢ 1 medium sized dry fish
‚Ä¢ 2 cups of roasted groundnuts
‚Ä¢ 2 cooking spoons of palm oil/ vegetable oil
‚Ä¢ ¬Ω medium sized onion - chopped
‚Ä¢ 4 plum tomatoes ‚Ä¢ 3 red scotch bonnets ‚Äúata rodo‚Äù
‚Ä¢ 3 tablespoons of crayfish ‚Äì ground
‚Ä¢ 1 tablespoon of dried pepper - optional
‚Ä¢ 2 calabash nutmeg ‚Ä¢ A handful of bitter leaves, scent leaves or pumpkin leaves ‚Äì chopped.

Method of preparation
-Roast the calabash nutmeg and pound into a smooth powder. -Season the beef and assorted meat with dried pepper and salt to taste. Cook for 25 minutes till tender. Soak the dry fish in hot water to soften and add to the cooked meat, then leave to cook for 5 minutes. -Blend the roasted groundnut into a smooth paste. Blend the tomato and pepper into a smooth puree. -Add oil into a pot and pre-heat for about 2 minutes. Add the chopped onion and fry until golden brown. Pour the groundnut paste into the pot and leave to cook for 10 minutes. -Add the tomato and pepper puree, stir to mix then add the meat, stock, crayfish and ground calabash nutmeg, stir and leave to cook for about 10 minutes. Add the chopped vegetable and leave to simmer for 3 minutes. -Serve hot.

Hello foodiesüòÄüòÉ have you tried Afang Soup? If you have never tried it, here is a quick #recipe for you. #FoodieFriday photo credit: @dobbyssignature

Ingredients
‚Ä¢ 450g of afang "okazi" leaves (Sliced thinly)
‚Ä¢ A bunch of water leaves
‚Ä¢ 400g of periwinkles - Optional
‚Ä¢ 400g of red beef
‚Ä¢ Assorted meat (Shaki & Pomo) ‚Ä¢ 2 fresh scotch bonnet pepper (ata rodo) ‚Ä¢ 2 seasoning cubes ‚Ä¢ 1 small stock fish ‚Ä¢ 1 small dry fish - optional ‚Ä¢ 1 cooking spoon of crayfish ‚Ä¢ 1 cup of palm oil ‚Ä¢ Salt to taste

Method of preparation
- Grinding or pounding the leaves with crayfish.
- Wash the periwinkles thoroughly and cut off the sharp edge.
-Wash the beef, stockfish, dryfish, shaki, pomo and place in a small pot. Add the seasoning cubes, salt, pepper and water to cook for 15 minutes.
- Add the palm oil and mix. Leave to cook for about 15 minutes till the stock in the pot reduces and the soup thickens.
- Add the crayfish, chopped water-leaves and periwinkles to cook for another 5 minutes. Ensure the stock in the pot is very little before adding water leaves.
-Serve hot with eba, fufu, wheatmeal, pounded yam etc

Don‚Äôt know what to cook for dinner? Why not try out @dobbyssignatures grilled fish recipe. Don‚Äôt forget to take a picture and tag #StanbicIBTC before eating J #FoodieFriday #Foodie

Ingredients
‚Ä¢ 1 medium sized croaker fish
‚Ä¢ 1 tablespoon of suya spice (optional)
‚Ä¢ 1 tablespoon of chili pepper
‚Ä¢ 1/2 crushed seasoning cube- (optional)
‚Ä¢ Cameroon pepper (optional)
‚Ä¢ 2 tablespoon of vegetable oil/olive oil
‚Ä¢ 2 cloves garlic (optional)
‚Ä¢ ¬Ω small blended red onion ‚Ä¢ Salt to taste
Method of preparation
-Scrape the scales off the fish and remove the fins. Rinse and gut the fish. Make 2 or 3 slashes on both sides of the fish and rinse thoroughly.
-Mix all the ingredients with the vegetable oil/olive oil in a small bowl. Place the fish on foil paper and coat the fish with the mixed ingredients. Cover and leave to marinate in the refrigerator for 30 minutes to 1hr.
-Place the fish in a preheated grill. Grill for about 5-7 minutes on each side till it flakes a little when touched. If you want a moist fish, it's best to leave the foil closed before placing the fish in the pre-heated grill. That way the fish would retain most of the moisture and nutrients. -Serve hot with fries.

Keep business and personal finances separate.
One of the biggest mistakes that small #business owners make is to use their business #account as a personal account and vice versa. If you adopt this practice you cannot keep track of the business and its profitability, especially if you are using debt to fund it. If you do not know what your net #profit is, there is no way you can know how to increase it. #FinancialTip

Prioritising your expenses. When drawing up your budget make sure your top priorities are listed first. Top priorities on any expense list are #food and shelter ‚Äì this could include your rent and levy or bond repayment. The next in line are essential utilities like water, electricity and transport. Insurance policies such as #life cover, car cover and society scheme contributions should be accounted for too. #Savings should also be a key consideration. It is worthwhile determining how much you are able to put away and allocate a fixed amount every month. #FinancialTip

You wanted to know how to make garden egg stew? Well here's how @dobbyssignature makes delicious garden egg stew. Try it out and tag us! What did you have for #dinner last night?
Ingredients
‚Ä¢ 7 medium size of garden egg
‚Ä¢ 1 cup palm oil ‚Ä¢ 1 medium sized smoked fish ‚Ä¢ 1 tablespoon ground pepper (chili or scotch bonnet) ‚Ä¢ 2 tablespoon of ogiri/dawadawa
‚Ä¢ 1 small onion ‚Ä¢ 3 tablespoon crayfish ‚Ä¢ Salt to taste 
Method of preparation
-Remove the stalk from the garden egg and rinse, boil for 10 minutes till soft. Blend or pound into a smooth paste.
-Heat up the oil in a small sized empty pot till it loosens up a little. Add the chopped onion, and ogiri/dawadawa. Stir fry for about 5 minutes. -Gently pour the ground garden eggs, smoked fish, crayfish, crushed seasoning, pepper and salt into the pot. Stir and leave to cook for about 10-15 minutes before turning off the burner.
-Serve with boiled, roasted/fried yam or plantain. #FoodieFriday #foodie #food

Know the difference between luxuries and necessities 
Knowing the difference between a ‚Äúwant‚Äù and a ‚Äúneed‚Äù can help you save money. If you don‚Äôt have to have it in order to survive, then it is a want. If the item doesn‚Äôt fit comfortably into your #budget, you need to set it aside until your budget is ready to handle the purchase. #FinancialTip

#FinancialTip Diversify your investments.
Diversification is an #investment technique that helps reduce risk by spreading out your assets across multiple classes against disastrous loss. Different assets - such as bonds, fixed deposit, mutual funds and stocks - will not react in the same way to adverse events. A combination of asset classes will help reduce your #portfolio's sensitivity to market swings. Unfortunately, even the best analysis of a company and its #financial statements cannot guarantee that it won't be a losing investment. Diversification helps protect you from catastrophic losses. #Money

The weekend is here, Ofe Nsala sounds great for lunch/dinner with the family. Will you be trying this? What is your favourite local soup? #FoodieFriday #Foodie #Foodgasm
Ingredients
‚Ä¢ 500g beef (Red meat)
‚Ä¢2 big sized cat fish
‚Ä¢ 1 medium sized dry fish /stock fish
‚Ä¢ 1 bulb of onion ‚Ä¢ 2 scotch Bonnets "Atarodo" ‚Ä¢ 1 tablespoon peppersoup spice ‚Ä¢ 3 stock cubes
‚Ä¢ Salt to taste ‚Ä¢ 2 tablespoon of crayfish
‚Ä¢ 2 tablespoon of thickener ‚Ä¢ 10 Uziza leaves
‚Ä¢ 5 Utazi leaves ‚Ä¢ 2 small sized of ogiri/dawadawa
‚Ä¢ Ngoloo or Isam (Periwinkle) 
Method of preparation
-Soak the stock fish and dry fish in hot water for 5 minutes till it‚Äôs soft. Remove the bones from the dry fish and set aside. -Wash the periwinkles.
-Blend/pound the onion and pepper with little water. -Place the beef in a medium sized pot and add little water to boil. Add the pounded or blended onion and pepper, salt and stock cubes to cook for 15 minutes till it‚Äôs tender.
-Once the meat is tender, add ¬Ω cup of water. Add the dissolved ogiri/dawadawa, cat fish, washed stock fish/dry fish, peppersoup spice, ground utazi & uziza seeds and cray fish. Leave to boil for 5 minutes.
-Once it starts to boil, add the tablespoons of thickener, stir and cover the pot. Leave to dissolve and thicken the soup then cook for 10 minutes to boil and thicken to desired taste. -Add the Periwinkles and chopped uziza and utazi leaves. Reduce the heat and leave to simmer for 3-5minutes
-Serve hot with your favourite Swallow.

Have a #will and update it. A will is a #legal document which sets out who would receive your assets when you pass on. Wills are not just for the rich - regardless of how much you earn or have, a will ensures that whatever personal belongings and assets you have will go to your family / beneficiaries. Nobody plans to die early, but if it suddenly happens and you are without a will, you'll be subjecting your #family and loved ones to a great deal of pain.
Let us ensure your loved ones are catered for in your will, email sitlagency@stanbicibtc.com to get started. #FinancialTip

Hello Foodies! When last did you enjoy a delicious meal of vegetable soup for lunch? You can try out our quick & easy recipe @dobbyssignature #FoodieFriday #Foodporn

Ingredients
‚Ä¢ 1 medium sized stock fish "Panla" ‚Ä¢ 3 pieces of smoked fish
‚Ä¢ 600g red beef meat ‚Ä¢ 5 red scotch bonnet pepper (Ata rodo)
‚Ä¢ 2 red capsicums (Red Bell pepper/Tatashe)
‚Ä¢ 4 pieces of chili pepper ‚Ä¢ 3 red onions ‚Ä¢ 5 cooking spoons of palm oil
‚Ä¢ 3 tablespoon of locust beans (Iru)
‚Ä¢ 1 cooking spoon of crayfish
‚Ä¢ 2 seasoning cubes
‚Ä¢ 1 tablespoon of curry powder
‚Ä¢ ¬Ω tablespoon of thyme ‚Ä¢ salt to taste ‚Ä¢ 3 bunches of spinach or ugu

Method of preparation
-Soak the stock fish in hot water for 10 minutes and rinse with cold water. Shred and remove the bones from the smoked fish.
-Wash and season the beef with salt, curry, thyme and onion. Cook on medium heat of 25 minutes, then add the smoked fish and stock fish to boil for 10 minutes more.
-Wash and blend the pepper and onion.
-In an empty pot, add 5 cooking spoons of palm oil and leave to heat for 2mins. Then add the chopped onion, blended pepper and locust beans. Stir fry for 4 minutes. -Gently add the stock including the meat, fish, 2 seasoning cubes, Crayfish and leave to boil for 6 minutes. -Add the chopped ugu or spinach leaves and stir to incorporate the mixture. Leave to cook for 8 minutes. -Serve with swallow, yam or rice.

Take your taste buds on a spectacular journey with @dobbyssignature yam pepper soup recipe. It will keep you warm during the rainy season. What do you call it in your native dialect? #FoodieFriday #food #foodie #foodgasm 
Ingredients for yam pepper soup
‚Ä¢ 2 fresh or 1 tablespoon of dry pepper ‚Ä¢ 1 medium sized red onion (chopped/ blended)
‚Ä¢ 5 smoked panla fish
‚Ä¢ 1 dried local catfish
‚Ä¢ 2 tablespoon cray fish
‚Ä¢ 1/2 cup palm oil
‚Ä¢ 2 seasoning cubes
‚Ä¢ salt to taste
‚Ä¢ a handful scent leaves 
Method of preparation
-Wash the cat fish and smoked panla fish thoroughly. Remove the bones, rinse and set aside. -Slice the yam and peel off the brown skin. Rinse with clean water, chop into smaller chunks and place in a medium sized pot.
-Add some the onion, pepper, salt to taste and just enough water to cover the yam in the pot. Cook for 10 mins. Once you notice the water in the pot starts to bubble, add a tablespoon of palm oil, washed fish, crushed seasoning and crayfish. Stir and cover the pot. Cook for another 15 minutes till the yam is soft.
-Turn off the burner and transfer the cooked yam into a different pot so it doesn't get soggy. When serving, dish out the yam and palm oil sprinkled with salt on a flat plate and the yam pepper soup in a different bowl. -Serve Hot!

#Ramadan is on, why not try out this delicious Shrimp coconut rice recipe by @dobbyssignature for your #Iftar meal. Don‚Äôt forget to invite your family and friends for a taste #FoodieFriday #foodporn 
Ingredients for shrimp coconut rice
‚Ä¢ 2 whole Coconuts
‚Ä¢ 3 cups rice
‚Ä¢ 200g fresh shrimp
‚Ä¢ 1 cup meat stock (either chicken stock, beef stock or turkey stock)
‚Ä¢ 2 seasoning cubes ‚Ä¢ salt to taste
‚Ä¢1 green pepper
‚Ä¢ spring onions
‚Ä¢ 1 red bell pepper
‚Ä¢1/2 red onion
‚Ä¢¬Ω cup vegetable oil/ butter

Method of preparation
-Rinse the rice with clean water and place in a pot. Cook on medium heat for 10 mins. Transfer the rice into a separate bowl and run clean water through it. Set aside.
-Break the coconuts, remove the flesh
-Pour the milk extract into a pot, add the parboiled rice, meat stock, shrimps, seasoning and salt to taste. Cover the pot and leave the rice to cook for about 15 minutes till the liquid in the pot dries up. -Chop the carrots, spring onions, bell peppers into smaller bits. Pour the vegetable oil or melt the butter in a pan. Add the chopped vegetables and stir-fry for 5 mins. -By now the rice would have absorbed the coconut and stock liquid.  Add the stir-fried vegetables into the coconut rice and mix. Leave to cook further for 5 minutes.
-Ready to eat

We hope you all take out time to relax this weekend and treat yourself to a delicious Abacha ncha (African Salad) @dobbyssignature. What is your favourite local delicacy? #FoodieFriday 
Ingredients
3 cups of palm oil 
4 pieces fresh fish (fried)
1 teaspoon of grounded ehu seeds (Calabash nutmeg) 
2 teaspoon of dry/ground pepper
4 garden eggs
Ogiri to taste
1 tablespoon of potash (Akaun)
3 utazi leaves (Gongronema latifolium)
Garden egg leaves
2 large red onion
4 handful of abacha
1 wrap of ugba (Ukpaka)
Seasoning to taste 
Method of preparation
-Soak the abacha in a bowl of warm water for 30 mins till soft then drain.
-Wash and chop the vegetables, garden eggs and dice one of the onions. Cut the other bulb of onion in ring like circles. -Pour 1 cup of warm water into a bowl and add the potash. Stir well.
-Add palm oil and the potash mixture in a pot.
Stir consistently till the palm oil and potash mixture turns into a yellow paste
-Add the ground ehu, seasoning, ground pepper, diced onions, Iru/ogiri and ugba (ukpaka) stir till the mixture is well incorporated. -Add your soaked abacha into the mixture.
-Garnish with the sliced utazi, garden egg leaves, onion rings, fish and Garden eggs
-Serve hot or cold.

Hello food lovers! Why not treat yourself this long weekend. When going shopping, you may want to buy ingredients to use for beef and potato soup recipe @dobbyssignature #FoodieFriday

Ingredients
500g of beef
600g of Irish potatoes
3 tablespoon of flour (to thicken)
3 large carrots
A bunch of spring onions
1 large red bell pepper
1 large green bell pepper
1 medium sized red onion
2 seasoning to taste
1 tablespoon curry powder
1 tablespoon thyme
Salt to taste

Method of preparation
-Dice the beef into smaller bits, rinse and place in a medium sized pot. Add water and salt to cook for 15 minutes. -Peel the Irish potatoes and cut into desired size. Rinse the potatoes and add into the pot with the cooked beef. -Add seasoning (curry powder & thyme) and cook on medium heat for about 15 minutes.
-Wash and slice the carrots, spring onions (cut lengthwise), red bell pepper (cut lengthwise), green bell pepper (cut lengthwise) and onion.
-In a separate bowl, add a little water into the flour and stir quickly making sure it doesn't form clumps. On low heat, gently add the flour liquid into the pot, stir continuously to mix properly and leave to thicken for 3-5minutes.
-Add the chopped vegetables and mix. Leave to cook for 5-7 minutes.
-Serve hot.

Cancel your unused memberships and subscriptions. It only devours your money. #FinancialTip

You know how we all sign up for a lot of services because, hey, we cannot just do without them? Yeah, that happens to a lot of people too. We have cable TV subscriptions, gym memberships, music streaming services, multiple ISPs for wifi and mobile, all the ecommerce and deal websites etc etc etc‚Ä¶
These all take quite a bit of money to keep up with and may severely limit what we have left in each income cycle after paying bills. What‚Äôs a relatively simple way to have more money left? Cancel them. Do you really need mobile internet when you can just carry a MiFi around? Do you need cable TV at home when you only sleep while you‚Äôre there? Do you need a gym when you can run for free? Ask some questions and make some painful decisions now. If financial independence is your aim, this is a great place to get back on track. What subscriptions do you think you can do away with this month?

If you have not decided what to cook this weekend, here is a recipe for Abak Atama Soup from @dobbyssignatures. Give it a try!

Ingredients
1800kg fresh palm nuts (Abak) 
800g beef or fresh fish
400g assorted meat (Pomo, Cow Intestines and Sharki) - optional
1 cup periwinkle (In shell with bottom part chopped off and washed)
1 cooking spoon crayfish (Ground)
2 medium sized dry or smoked fish
1 medium sized stock fish head 
1/2 cup smoked/ fresh prawn
1 tablespoon of dry Pepper
2 Seasoning cubes
Salt to taste
1 handful Atama leaf "Efik" (Beletientien leaves) - Sliced/crushed 
Method of preparation
-Wash the palm nuts and place in a medium sized pot and add clean water to cover the palm nuts to cook for 15-20 mins till the nuts get soft. -Strain the liquid used in boiling out and pound the palmnuts in a mortar till the skin separates from the kernel, scoop the pounded nuts into a clean bowl and add water. Squeeze and strain the palm oil into a bowl. -Wash and seasoning the Beef and assorted meat in a pot. Cook till the meat gets tender. -Soak the stock fish in hot water to soften for 10 minutes then rinse with clean water. -Pour the extracted palm nut liquid in a medium sized pot and cook for about 10 minutes. Add the Beef and assorted meat (Including the stock "Meat water").
-Add the smoked fish, stock fish, ground crayfish and shrimp. Stir and leave to cook for 25-30mins. -Add the Periwinkles and crushed Atama leaves into the pot of soup, stir and leave to simmer for 5 mins.
-Serve hot. #FoodieFriday

Hello foodies. Enjoy our grilled lamb chops recipe. #FoodieFriday 
Ingredients for Grilled lamb chops

2 large garlic cloves (crushed)
1 teaspoon fresh thyme leaves
Pinch of red pepper
Salt to taste
2 tablespoons extra-virgin olive oil
6 lamb chops, about 3/4-inch thick

Method of preparation
-Mix the garlic, fresh thyme, salt and 1 tablespoon of olive oil in large bowl. -Add lamb and turn to coat with the mixture. -Marinate at room temperature for at least 30 minutes or 1 hour.
-Preheat oven to 400¬∞F. -Heat remaining 1 tablespoon olive oil in ovenproof skillet over high heat. -Add lamb and cook until it's brown, about 3 minutes.
-Transfer skillet to oven and roast lamb chops for 10 minutes.
-Leave to cool for 5 minutes.

Ofe Onugbu "bitter leaf soup" is a tasty soup that is very rich in vitamins and helps reduce high blood sugar level. Try out @dobbyssignatures recipe for Ofe Onugbu. Tag a friend who will love this #FoodieFriday

Ingredients
3 handfuls of bitter leaf
1 tablespoon fermented oil seed (Ogiri)
600g red beef
500g assorted meat: shaki, ponmo - Optional
1 Cup periwinkles - Optional
Stock fish/ dry Fish
1 rodo - diced
2 cooking spoon palm oil
1 cooking spoon Crayfish
2 seasoning cubes
Salt to taste

Method of preparation
- Wash the bitter leaf by hand thoroughly to remove the bitter taste or boil in a pot for 10mins.
- Strain with a sieve and rinse severally with cold water. Squeeze off excess water and set aside.
-Wash the beef, assorted meat, Periwinkles, stock fish/ dry Fish, pepper. Place in a medium sized pot, add some salt and boil for 15 minutes.
- Add the seasoning and ogiri into the pot and mix. Leave to boil for another 5mins - Add the Cocoyam paste, leave to dissolve then add the palm oil and crayfish leave to thicken.
- Add the washed bitter leaf and mix. Leave to boil for 10mins more before turning off the burner. - Serve hot with your favourite swallow (Eba, Amala, fufu).

Hello food lovers‚Ä¶ Variety is the spice of life... Treat your guest to delicious finger foods- Onion rings, spring rolls, fries, chicken and fish fingers #FoodieFriday #Foodie #FingerFood

Spring Roll Recipe

Ingredients:
Shrimps ‚Äì 10-12 pieces 
Ground beef or Sausage- 1/2 cup
Salt ‚Äì To taste
Pepper- To taste
Seasoning - 1 cube
Spring Roll Wrapper ‚Äì 12-15
Vegetable oil ‚Äì for frying
Soy sauce

Preparation method
- Boil the shrimps for 5 minutes and set aside.
- Place a pot on medium heat, add a little oil and throw in the ground beef.
- Cook until the beef is brown, then add the shrimps, seasoning, salt and pepper
- Mix and let cool - Fill one side of each spring roll wrapper, then roll up neatly. -With your wraps all done, fry till the spring rolls are golden brown and crisp.
-Enjoy your spring rolls with the soy sauce.

A yummy salad is always a good idea to accompany your lunch. Here is a quick & easy recipe!

Ingredients
1 bunch of lettuce, 5 carrots, 4 potatoes, 2 small cucumbers, 2 eggs, 1 tin of baked beans, 200g sweet corn, 5 tomatoes, and salad dressing.

Preparation - Boil the eggs while cooking the potatoes - Wash the vegetables with vinegar or salty water, cut the lettuce into thin shreds; grate the carrots; peel and cut the boiled potatoes into cubes.
- Peel the shells off the boiled eggs, slice into thin shapes and set aside.
- Peel the cucumbers, remove the seeds and cut in strips; cut tomatoes into small pieces.
- Add ALL the ingredients except the eggs into a big bowl in little batches.
- Now, place the sliced eggs on the salad. Cover the bowl and place in the fridge for at least one hour. This helps all the flavours and aromas mix well in the dish.
Serve with the salad dressings of your choice.
#FoodieFriday #Salad
